news.title: How Bari Weiss‚Äô Takeover of CBS News Shifts the Media World | Analysis
news.text:
The acquisition of Bari Weiss‚Äô right-leaning The Free Press by Paramount places her in a disruptive role atop the beleaguered but storied CBS News. With her unprecedented ascent to become editor in chief, the move heralds the arrival of a divisive, ferociously ambitious figure with distinct political views overseeing one of the world‚Äôs most consequential news operations.

What could go wrong? 

When asked about his plans for CBS News in August, Paramount‚Äôs newly minted CEO, David Ellison, told reporters that he didn‚Äôt want to ‚Äúpoliticize anything‚Äù as he took the reins of the historic company. But in bringing aboard Weiss, someone who has no experience in broadcast news and whose work has launched multiple firestorms over hot-button political issues including gender identity, Israel and Gaza and the influence of tech bros on Washington, Ellison has seemingly undermined that claim.

On Monday, Paramount said it would acquire The Free Press for what insiders say is $150 million in stock and cash. Weiss will report directly to Ellison while CBS News President and Executive Editor Tom Cibrowski will continue to manage its day-to-day operations and report to George Cheeks. One person with knowledge of the conversations described the role as consulting at a high level rather than running the daily news operation, as Weiss will also continue to run The Free Press.

The person also told TheWrap that with Weiss‚Äô hiring, Susan Zirinsky ‚Äî who was brought on earlier this year to oversee news after the previous owner Shari Redstone bristled at some of the network‚Äôs coverage of the war in Gaza ‚Äî will exit that role.

Weiss‚Äô appointment upends the conventional thinking around how a newsroom should be run, a shift that is happening as journalists see their media organizations face increasing financial and political pressure. At the same time, trust in media in the U.S. has sunk to an all-time low as President Trump regularly attacks any coverage he deems remotely unfavorable.

For CBS News, the move lays the groundwork for more wrenching changes that come on top of the additional layoffs expected as Paramount seeks to cut costs. 

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always seen her as a point-of-view journalist ‚Äî it‚Äôs one of the first things you can say about her ‚Äî but CBS News doesn‚Äôt think of itself as a POV news network,‚Äù Jay Rosen, a media critic and former journalism professor at New York University, told TheWrap. ‚ÄúThere is no point of view to the news division as they imagine their work, and so I think she is very much different than [what] the culture of CBS News has been for a long time.‚Äù

Because of Weiss‚Äô unorthodox r√©sum√© for this sort of position ‚Äî her experience is rooted in opinion journalism, as an anti-woke New York Times columnist and Wall Street Journal op-ed editor ‚Äî the perception is that the hire has more to do with shifting to a right-of-center political ideology than a grand vision for CBS News.

Indeed, in a post on The Free Press on Monday, Weiss outlined what she sees as a mission to serve the ‚Äúoverwhelming majority‚Äù of Americans in the center of the political spectrum.

‚ÄúIf the illiberalism of our institutions has been the story of the last decade, we now face a different form of illiberalism emanating from our fringes. On the one hand, an America-loathing far left. On the other, a history-erasing far right. These extremes do not represent the majority of the country, but they have increasing power in our politics, our culture, and our media ecosystem,‚Äù she wrote.

‚ÄúOverlooked by all these so-called interlocutors are the enormous numbers of smart, politically mixed, pragmatic Americans. The people who believe, unapologetically, in the American project. This is the actual mainstream. These people are the overwhelming majority of the country. And they are being ill-served.‚Äù

Network sources were reluctant to discuss what Weiss‚Äô role would mean ahead of the announcement, but they pointed to the tumult that has enveloped CBS since 2023 ‚Äî which has included its coverage of the Israel-Gaza conflict, its various leadership changes and Trump‚Äôs legal assault on its journalism ‚Äî to outline the challenges Weiss would face in earning the newsroom‚Äôs trust.

‚ÄúCBS News is a very complicated, very tricky organization,‚Äù a person close to the network told TheWrap. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a viper‚Äôs pit, and it is very, very tricky to bring new people into CBS News and have them be accepted.‚Äù

Another senior insider said that Weiss‚Äô role was more titular than operational, and that it would need to evolve with time.

CBS News declined to comment.

In a note to staff on Monday, Weiss outlined her position as a ‚Äúchampion‚Äù for journalistic values: 

‚ÄúI stand for the same core journalistic values that have defined this profession since the beginning, and I will continue to champion them alongside you.‚Äù

A new news era

Paramount‚Äôs purchase of The Free Press, the ‚Äúanti-woke‚Äù contrarian outlet Weiss founded in 2022, represents an astonishing exit for a media company, much less one that is only three years old. 

But CBS News has been in a bind, and Ellison was determined to make a change.

CBS News had already taken measures to mollify conservative critics since Ellison took the reins of Paramount. It appointed an ombudsman, Kenneth R. Weinstein, a former CEO of conservative think tank Hudson Institute, who was revealed to have a history of donating to Trump-affiliated groups.

Yet beyond questions about her ability to run an enterprise of the scale of CBS News, Weiss, 41, is a particularly divisive figure, having achieved much of her fame less for the job she did as an opinion columnist for The New York Times than the very public manner in which she left it, tendering her resignation in 2020 by accusing the paper of creating a ‚Äúhostile work environment‚Äù due to her right-leaning views.

Weiss sparked additional headlines by serving as one of the journalists to whom Elon Musk reached out to produce the ‚ÄúTwitter Files,‚Äù an exercise intended to expose the platform‚Äôs hostility to conservatives after he acquired it in 2022. The much-hyped effort drew partisan cheers but ended without yielding any significant revelations and was seen as a blow to Weiss‚Äôs credibility.

‚ÄúThe fact that Elon Musk decided to come to a bunch of people essentially with newsletters rather than The Washington Post and The New York Times tells you a lot about where real trust in the media these days actually lies,‚Äù Weiss said on a podcast in 2022 regarding the Twitter Files.

Weiss‚Äô pending deal, not surprisingly, drew an endorsement from another journalist involved in the Twitter Files, Matt Taibbi, who exulted in ‚Äúlegacy media‚Äôs tears‚Äù over the reports.

The Free Press, meanwhile, has become a mirror of Weiss‚Äô politics, although even there she has elicited controversy. She conducted a podcast interview with billionaire tech mogul Peter Thiel, where she declined to challenge him on his more controversial beliefs ‚Äî such as his position against democracy and in favor of the survival of the elite in a tech ‚Äúsingularity‚Äù with machines ‚Äî in contradiction to her publication‚Äôs promise of ‚Äúfierce independence.‚Äù

In their lengthy sit-down after the 2024 election, Thiel referred to Democrats as ‚Äúthe evil party‚Äù and spoke of the political left as a ‚Äúprogressive cult‚Äù and ‚Äúnot very American,‚Äù to no pushback from Weiss.

All told, it‚Äôs an unlikely track record for a journalist set to take on a major role in one of the largest and most storied news organizations in the world, following in the footsteps of Walter Cronkite and Edward R. Murrow. 

A spokesperson for The Free Press did not respond to a request for comment or to make Weiss available for an interview.

Joining an embattled newsroom 

The Free Press acquisition follows several blows to CBS News‚Äô morale. Much of that involved Paramount‚Äôs settlement of Trump‚Äôs ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù lawsuit, based on a flimsy claim that the editing of a Kamala Harris interview hurt his campaign, and concessions made to Federal Communications Commission chairman Brendan Carr, including the hiring of an ombudsman.

Weiss could plunge the mood even lower, in what could be interpreted as another move to placate Trump. CBS seemingly took another step in that direction by announcing last month that it would change its interview policy for ‚ÄúFace the Nation‚Äù after the Department of Homeland Security accused the network of a ‚Äúwhitewash‚Äù for airing a shortened version of a Kristi Noem interview answer related to undocumented migrant Kilmar Abrego Garcia.

‚ÄúAbsorbing The Free Press seems to him to be a way to be on both sides, and to prevent Donald Trump from attacking his company,‚Äù Rosen said regarding Ellison. ‚ÄúSomehow, he sees Bari as an answer to, ‚ÄòHow do you prevent the President of the United States from going into attack mode constantly?‚Äô‚Äù

Weiss, who is described by those who know her as both charismatic and controlling, represents a marked departure from the more staid, traditional values of CBS News. Her arrival thus sets up a potential ideological struggle and a clash between old and new, handing the keys to a legacy media outlet to someone who, with her frequently expressed disdain for traditional media, has made her name as a provocateur.

Weiss‚Äô career has been no stranger to controversy, and her age and apparent success launching a digital enterprise could be indicative of the ‚Äúnext generation‚Äù studio that Ellison ‚Äî a fellow millennial ‚Äî has discussed creating. 

But she would come to the process with both a huge learning curve and considerable skepticism from the rank and file at the news division.

‚ÄúBari Weiss brings a more center right perspective to a mainstream media that generally leans left and I imagine that‚Äôs part of her appeal,‚Äù said Liz Spayd, a lecturer at Georgetown University who worked as the New York Times‚Äô final public editor.

From columnist to entrepreneur

A native of a Pittsburgh suburb who studied at both New York‚Äôs Columbia University and Jerusalem‚Äôs Hebrew University, Weiss got her start at the Israeli newspaper Haaretz and the Jewish newspaper The Forward before two stints at The Wall Street Journal and then the New York Times. 

Her opinion pieces at the Journal often straddled the line between challenging the Rupert Murdoch-owned paper‚Äôs editorially conservative tilt and progressives‚Äô leftward bent, but she told Vanity Fair in 2019 she often felt like the most liberal voice at the paper after Donald Trump‚Äôs election.

‚ÄúI wanted people to see how I felt about this, and what I thought it meant for the country,‚Äù Weiss told the magazine. ‚ÄúI realized I had to leave.‚Äù

She moved to the Times in 2017, where her opinions roiled those across the political spectrum ‚Äî and her Times colleagues ‚Äî with pieces often targeting social justice movements. Her headlines included those titled ‚ÄúThree Cheers for Cultural Appropriation,‚Äù which advocated for Americans to blend cultures outside racial and ethnic lines, and ‚ÄúMeet the Renegades of the Intellectual Dark Web,‚Äù where she profiled and gave voice to incendiary figures like Jordan Peterson and Dave Rubin. 

In her July 2020 resignation letter to publisher A.G. Sulzberger, which is still pinned to her website, Weiss claimed to have been bullied by colleagues because of her views, and accused the paper of ‚Äúilliberalism,‚Äù of being intolerant of views outside of a progressive orthodoxy.

‚ÄúThe lessons that ought to have followed the election [of Donald Trump] ‚Äî lessons about the importance of understanding other Americans, the necessity of resisting tribalism, and the centrality of the free exchange of ideas to a democratic society ‚Äî have not been learned,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúInstead, a new consensus has emerged in the press, but perhaps especially at this paper: that truth isn‚Äôt a process of collective discovery, but an orthodoxy already known to an enlightened few whose job is to inform everyone else.‚Äù

Weiss launched the Substack blog ‚ÄúCommon Sense‚Äù in 2021, which she later turned into The Free Press in 2022 alongside her wife, Nellie Bowles, and her sister, Suzy Weiss. She initially framed the organization as one dedicated to independent journalism ‚Äî albeit one that‚Äôs a home for causes personal to her, including combating antisemitism. At times, the website has turned into a platform for ‚Äúanti-woke‚Äù writers and perspectives eschewed by mainstream media. 

NPR‚Äôs former senior business editor, Uri Berliner, wrote a lengthy takedown of the public radio network‚Äôs perceived liberal bias in The Free Press in April 2024. Two months and a suspension later, he joined Weiss‚Äô website as a senior editor.

The Free Press has also taken investments from right-leaning millionaires, including tech investors Marc Andreessen, David Sacks and the U.K.-based Paul Marshall, who owns the conservative British broadcaster GB News, according to the Financial Times.

As the New York Times reported in a profile last year, Weiss has positioned the site as ‚Äúa teller of dangerous truths,‚Äù catering to an audience that shares her views that ‚Äúelite universities have lost the plot; that legacy outlets have lost their minds; that Ms. Weiss knows the way forward.‚Äù

Critics, however, see Weiss primarily as a gifted self-promoter who has carved out a posture that hinges on being anti-‚Äúwoke‚Äù above all else. The Nation‚Äôs Jack Mirkinson was particularly blunt, citing The Free Press‚Äô anti-trans ‚Äúpropaganda‚Äù as an example, and referring to the prospect of Weiss overseeing CBS News as a sign that ‚Äúgrifters are taking over establishment media.‚Äù

Weiss‚Äô website has found an audience, with an estimated 1.5 million free and paid subscribers, according to The New York Times, and roughly 50 employees as of August 2024 (though it lost a number of key hires this year). The outlet is estimated to have about $14 million in annual revenue and about 140,000 paying subscribers, according to TheWrap‚Äôs reporting. 

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt have experience running a broadcast network or sprawling newsroom anywhere near the size of CBS but she is unquestionably a successful media entrepreneur at a time when we need more of them,‚Äù Spayd said.

What is less certain is just how disruptive Weiss will be to an embattled news organization already bracing for chaos. 

Sharon Waxman contributed reporting to this story.
news.summary:
The founder of The Free Press will become chief editor of  the storied newsroom after a career of expressing disdain for traditional journalism


The post How Bari Weiss‚Äô Takeover of CBS News Shifts the Media World | Analysis appeared first on TheWrap.
news.author: Corbin Bolies

news.title: Paramount officially acquires anti-woke The Free Press and names Bari Weiss CBS News‚Äô editor-in-chief
news.text:
Paramount Skydance has acquired the anti-woke digital media outlet The Free Press for $150 million and named the site‚Äôs ‚Äúheterodox‚Äù founder Bari Weiss as CBS News‚Äô editor-in-chief, the companies announced on Monday.

The move, which was in the works for months and had been deemed ‚Äúimminent‚Äù in recent days, is just the latest shake-up at the Tiffany Network following the politically fraught merger between Paramount and Skydance Media this past summer, which saw Paramount‚Äôs former ownership pay President Donald Trump $16 million to settle a ‚Äúmeritless‚Äù lawsuit over a 60 Minutes interview with Kamala Harris.

This is a breaking news story...
news.summary: Bari Weiss is now the top editor of CBS News.
news.author: Justin Baragona

news.title: From Dan Rather to ‚Äî¬†Bari Weiss? How far CBS News has fallen
news.text:
Twenty years ago, when Dan Rather was pushed out from CBS News following a controversial 2004 report on former President George W. Bush‚Äôs National Guard service, it was a massive scandal. While many remember it for being predicated upon shaky documents, it was also incredibly prophetic about the future media landscape: One that‚Äôs rapidly consumed by corporate interests, political pressure and the erosion of editorial independence. 

After a 24-year tenure in the anchor chair of the ‚ÄúCBS Evening News,‚Äù Rather did not depart quietly. ‚ÄúThey sacrificed support for independent journalism for corporate financial gain, and in so doing, I think they undermined a lot at CBS News,‚Äù he told CNN‚Äôs Larry King in 2007. ‚ÄúSomebody, sometime, has got to take a stand and say democracy cannot survive, much less thrive with the level of big corporate and big government interference and intimidation in news.‚Äù Rather filed an unsuccessful $70 million lawsuit against the network, and in the years that followed, he delivered a series of prescient warnings about the chilling effects of political appeasement. 

Despite the narrative pushed by the right-wing campaign against him ‚Äî which was led by Bush‚Äôs White House ‚Äî Rather remained adamant, even through reputational degradation, that the real threat to journalism wasn‚Äôt liberal bias or declining ratings, but the corrosive takeover of the fourth estate by corporate and ideological power. Now, two decades later, CBS News has reached the end of a long corridor he warned us would lead to disaster. 

This morning it was announced that Paramount, CBS‚Äôs parent company, has named Bari Weiss as the editor-in-chief of CBS News. A former New York Times opinion page editor who resigned after she claimed to have been ‚Äúsilenced‚Äù amidst the George Floyd protests in 2020, Weiss went on to found the Free Press on Substack. With roughly 1.5 million subscribers, the newsletter built its audience on contrarian opinion columns and critiques of ‚Äúthe woke left.‚Äù Weiss has cultivated a reputation as a reasonable dissident, eliding outright partisanship and granting her the appearance of neutrality while claiming the mantle to question progressive orthodoxy. 

In a letter to Free Press subscribers, Weiss promised to deliver more of the same in her new role at CBS News. Describing the newsletter‚Äôs acquisition and her new position as a ‚Äúonce-in-a-lifetime opportunity,‚Äù she noted the move ‚Äúgives The Free Press a chance to help reshape a storied media organization‚Äîto help guide CBS News into a future that honors those great values that underpin The Free Press and the best of American journalism. And in doing so, to bring our mission to millions of people.‚Äù

Part of her mission at the Tiffany Network will be to tackle ‚Äúilliberalism emanating from our fringes.‚Äù Weiss wrote, ‚ÄúOn the one hand, an America-loathing far left. On the other, a history-erasing far right. These extremes do not represent the majority of the country, but they have increasing power in our politics, our culture, and our media ecosystem. Overlooked by all these so-called interlocutors are the enormous numbers of smart, politically mixed, pragmatic Americans. The people who believe, unapologetically, in the American project.‚Äù

On Thursday, the New York Times reported that Paramount‚Äôs acquisition of the conservative outlet would value Weiss‚Äô operation at around $150 million. That‚Äôs quite the leap for a 41-year-old first made famous for her role in the battle for academic freedom in the Middle East Studies Department at Columbia University. At the same time Rather‚Äôs controversial reporting was challenging a sitting president, Weiss led a campus campaign designed to ruin the careers of Arab professors by equating their criticisms of Israel with anti-Semitism. Decades later, Weiss‚Äô Free Press repeatedly criticized CBS News‚Äô coverage of Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza. 

Weiss appears to have been hand-picked for the position by tech billionaire Larry Ellison, whose company Skydance recently purchased CBS through a purchase of its parent company, Paramount ‚Äî and whose Oracle Corporation was just handed virtual control of TikTok in the U.S. by President Donald Trump. The Free Press‚Äô stridently pro-Israel coverage, focusing on U.S.-centered culture wars, like criticizing campus protests rather than the bombing campaign or famine in Gaza, made Weiss an ideal candidate for Ellison‚Äôs apparent vision to reshape the global narrative around Israel‚Äôs war ahead of the third anniversary of Oct. 7. 

Ellison, a former Democrat turned top Trump donor, is one of the world‚Äôs largest financial supporters of Israel‚Äôs military forces. His recent purchases of Paramount and TikTok signal that he will seek to use his massive new media footprint to maintain an environment where U.S. support for Israel remains strong, even while the American public‚Äôs support for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Nentanyah‚Äôs government is drastically declining. Weiss, for her part, is said to report directly to Ellison‚Äôs son, David, the chief executive of the new Paramount Skydance company ‚Äî and whom she thanked profusely in her letter ‚Äî rather than CBS News president Tom Cibrowsk, who is reportedly preparing to lay off up to 10% of CBS News‚Äô staff in the coming weeks. 

Want more sharp takes on politics? Sign up for our free newsletter, Standing Room Only, written by Amanda Marcotte, now also a weekly show on YouTube or wherever you get your podcasts.

‚ÄúThe fact that we don‚Äôt have money to pay journalists, but we have money to pay Bari Weiss between $100 and 200 million is indicative of what the Ellisons‚Äô true goal here is,‚Äù one network correspondent told the Independent. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs not journalism.‚Äù

CBS staff, according to reporting, worry that bringing in Weiss will reduce the willingness of the network to maintain a modicum of editorial independence to cover pro‚ÄëPalestinian views in a balanced manner. Some see Weiss as likely to tamp down coverage of Gaza or to emphasize narratives that align with the Israeli government‚Äôs ideology. 

Despite having zero broadcast news experience, Weiss will oversee the Tiffany Network‚Äôs storied ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù program. Earlier this year, several of the show‚Äôs top executives resigned after Paramount agreed to a $16 million settlement with Trump, who had sued the network over the program‚Äôs October 2024 interview with then‚ÄëVice President Kamala Harris. Despite the fact that CBS followed standard journalistic practices, Trump alleged the interview was edited in a way that falsely portrayed her responses ‚Äî and gave her an advantage over him. Now, after the settlement and ahead of the official change in leadership, CBS News is now reportedly negotiating a potential ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù sit-down with the president. Last month, the network named Kenneth Weinstein, the CEO of a conservative think tank and one-time Trump appointee, as the ombudsman for CBS News. 

‚ÄúI think the ombudsman, Bari Weiss, and the impending massive layoffs that are coming in a couple of weeks have everyone just kind of freaking out, like, literally freaking out,‚Äù another CBS journalist told the Independent. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a good place right now. There was a proper way to do this and a not proper way, and they‚Äôre doing it in the non-proper way, and maybe that‚Äôs by design.‚Äù

Ultimately, Ellison‚Äôs megacorporation needs regulatory approval from Trump‚Äôs administration, and Weiss‚Äô elevation is likely meant to appease the president‚Äôs complaints about ideological diversity. By bringing in a high‚Äëprofile critic of progressive media bias, CBS News can plausibly argue that it‚Äôs trying to include conservative perspectives. It‚Äôs a strategic move to reshape CBS News‚Äô identity from the independence of the Rather era. Notably, it comes as the Washington Post, owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, issued a new directive that the paper‚Äôs opinion section emphasize ‚Äúpersonal liberties and free markets‚Äù ‚Äî a rightward shift that has prompted high-profile exits from several longtime columnists, including Eugene Robinson and Ruth Marcus.

The capture of CBS News by a Trump-aligned billionaire and a culture warrior with an editorial agenda is not just a sign of media decay. It‚Äôs a sign that democracy‚Äôs referees are being replaced by players. The supposed watchdogs are now operatives. Dan Rather knew this was coming. He warned us that once news organizations are fully absorbed by corporate and political interests, they stop telling truth to power ‚Äî and start laundering power‚Äôs version of the truth. 

‚ÄúI still know many people there, and I‚Äôm not ashamed to say that my heart is still there and probably always will be in a way, but this is an extremely tough time for them,‚Äù Rather recently said of CBS News. Speaking last month to SiriusXM host Andy Cohen, the legendary journalist lamented Ellison‚Äôs takeover. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be interesting to see how much, if any, pressure the new owners put on them to change the coverage to be more pro-Trump than to [be] independent news.‚Äù
news.summary: The Tiffany Network has become a battlefield in the billionaires' war on journalism
news.author: Sophia Tesfaye

news.title: Free Press co-founder Bari Weiss named editor-in-chief of CBS News
news.text: Paramount has acquired The Free Press, a four-year-old digital news platform, and will make its co-founder Bari Weiss editor-in-chief of CBS News, the company announced Monday. The official announcement came after months of speculation on the deal and Weiss' high profile role within the news division. Weiss, 41, will report to Paramount Chief Executive David Ellison, who personally courted the former New York Times journalist. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to welcome Bari and The Free Press to Paramount and CBS News. Bari is a proven champion of independent, principled journalism, and I am confident her entrepreneurial drive and editorial vision will invigorate CBS News," Ellison said in a statement. "This move is part of Paramount‚Äôs bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects ‚Äî directly and passionately ‚Äî to audiences around the world.‚Äù Paramount said Weiss will "shape editorial policies, champion core values across platforms and lead innovation in how the organization reports and delivers the news." The union of The Free Press and CBS News will be one of the most closely watched lab experiments in the modern media era. Weiss has no experience in television or running an editorial operation on the scale of CBS News, which has more than 1,000 employees. Paramount is paying around $150 million in cash and stock for The Free Press, a feisty, upstart operation that generated attention through opinion pieces and podcasts with a strong point of view. Its favorite targets are the excesses of progressive left and purveyors of so-called "woke" policies. CBS News is a traditional mass appeal network TV operation with a proud legacy of journalistic excellence and the home of popular franchises "60 Minutes" and "CBS Sunday Morning." But the division has struggled to deal with the shifts in audience habits brought about by streaming video and social media. Weiss is a provocateur who famously resigned from her high profile role in the opinion section of the New York Times in 2020, citing bullying by her colleagues and a hostile work environment as the reasons. Weiss acknowledged the division's legacy in a note sent to CBS News staffers after her appointment was announced. "Growing up, CBS was a deep family tradition," Weiss said. "Whenever i hear the tick, tick, tick or that trumpet fanfare, it sends me right back to our den in Pittsburgh. The opportunity to build on that legacy ‚Äî and to renew it in an era that so desperately needs it ‚Äî is an extraordinary privilege." Weiss also ascends at a time when Trump has threatened news operations with lawsuits and regulatory action, such as pulling station TV licenses over what he believes is unfair criticism of him and his administration. Paramount agreed to pay $16 million to settle a Trump lawsuit making the dubious claim that a "60 Minutes" interview with Kamala Harris was deceptively edited to aid her 2024 presidential election campaign against him. CBS News has never had an executive with the title editor-in-chief before naming Weiss to the role. It still has a president ‚Äî Tom Cibrowski ‚Äî a former ABC News executive hired earlier this year who will remain in his role and continue to report to to Paramount TV Media President George Cheeks. In her note, Weiss told her staffers her goal in the coming weeks is to learn "what's working and what isn't, and your thoughts on how we can make CBS News the most trusted news organization in America and the world. I'll approach it the way any reporter would ‚Äî with an open mind, a fresh notebook, and an urgent deadline." The Free Press, which has around 170,000 paid subscribers, will continue as its own independent brand, with its own podcasts and live events business.
news.summary: CBS News parent Paramount will also acquire The Free Press for $150 million in cash and stock.
news.author: Stephen Battaglio

news.title: Paramount Acquires Bari Weiss‚Äô¬†the Free Press, Names Her CBS News Editor in Chief
news.text:
Paramount has acquired Bari Weiss‚Äô right-leaning publication The Free Press and named its founder as editor in chief of CBS News. The Monday move makes apparent CEO David Ellison‚Äôs desire to shift the Tiffany Network‚Äôs news division in a more conservative direction.

Weiss will report directly to Ellison, who said in a statement that he was ‚Äúthrilled‚Äù to welcome Weiss aboard.

‚ÄúBari is a proven champion of independent, principled journalism, and I am confident her entrepreneurial drive and editorial vision will invigorate CBS News,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúThis move is part of Paramount‚Äôs bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects ‚Äì directly and passionately ‚Äì to audiences around the world.‚Äù

Financial terms were not disclosed, but insiders told TheWrap that Paramount had purchased the three-year-old website for $150 million in a cash and stock deal, an astonishing outcome for a media website that insiders estimate to generate about $14 million in revenue, mostly from subscriptions.

Weiss‚Äô focus will be to ‚Äúshape editorial priorities, champion core values across platforms and lead innovation‚Äù in CBS News‚Äô journalism.

‚ÄúThis partnership allows our ethos of fearless, independent journalism to reach an enormous, diverse and influential audience,‚Äù Weiss said in a statement. ‚ÄúWe honor the extraordinary legacy of CBS News by committing ourselves to a singular mission: building the most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.‚Äù

In a note to CBS staffers, Weiss described her family‚Äôs history with the CBS News brand and said she would spend her first few weeks on a listening tour at the network. 

‚ÄúI stand for the same core journalistic values that have defined this profession since the beginning, and I will continue to champion them alongside you,‚Äù she shared.

CBS News President and Executive Editor Tom Cibrowski, a well-liked executive who assumed the role in March, will remain at the organization. The two will work together, though Cibrowski will continue to report to CBS‚Äôs CEO of TV Media, George Cheeks.

Ellison told staffers in a memo on Monday that Weiss had an ‚Äúincredible energy, judgment and perception for what will resonate with audiences.‚Äù

‚ÄúWorking alongside our exceptionally talented colleagues at CBS News, she will help ensure that our reporting remains relevant, accessible and ‚Äî most importantly ‚Äî trusted in this new era for American media,‚Äù he wrote.

The announcement caps Ellison‚Äôs monthslong pursuit of Weiss‚Äô outlet, one first reported in June. It signals a significant new era for a global news operation that has traditionally pursued objectivity but has been marred by attacks from President Trump and others over coverage they‚Äôve deemed biased and adversarial. Paramount appointed a conservative think tank veteran, Kenneth R. Weinstein, as its internal watchdog last month, just after the Ellisons took ownership of Paramount from the Redstone family.

The Free Press acquisition follows several blows to CBS News‚Äô morale. Much of that involved Paramount‚Äôs settlement of Trump‚Äôs ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù lawsuit, based on a flimsy claim that the editing of a Kamala Harris interview hurt his campaign. Paramount settled the lawsuit for $16 million.

TheWrap reported last month that Weiss would join CBS News in a top role.

Paramount said Weiss would remain editor and CEO of The Free Press, which will operate as a standalone outlet alongside CBS News. The website has often crusaded against policies or cultural moments it has deemed ‚Äúwoke,‚Äù and it has not wavered from hot-button political issues involving gender identity, Israel and Gaza and the convergence of tech and Washington. 

Weiss maintains ties to controversial tech leaders, having interviewed the reclusive Palantir chairman, Peter Thiel, last year and co-hosted a pre-inauguration party in January with Elon Musk‚Äôs X.

The acquisition continues a spree of deals by the Ellison-led Paramount, which acquired the rights of UFC games; the rights to the animated satire ‚ÄúSouth Park‚Äù; and deals with filmmakers James Mangold and ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù creators the Duffer Brothers. Ellison has also been reportedly interested in purchasing Warner Bros. Discovery, though he has yet to place a bid for the company.
news.summary:
The purchase ends a monthslong saga over David Ellison‚Äôs pursuit of the ‚Äúanti-woke‚Äù¬†outlet


The post Paramount Acquires Bari Weiss‚Äô¬†the Free Press, Names Her CBS News Editor in Chief appeared first on TheWrap.
news.author: Corbin Bolies
